elements.content: Eight ZnII and CdII coordination complexes, {[Zn3(nbta)2(bpy)2(H2O)2](H2O)2} n (1), [Zn4(nbta)2(bpe)2(OH)2] n (2), {[Cd3(nbta)2(bpy)5(H2O)2](H2O)6} n (3), {[Cd3(nbta)2(bpe)2(H2O)2](H2O)2} n (4), [Zn2(Hbta)2(bpy)2(H2O)2](H2O) (5), [Zn(bta)(Hbpe)] n (6), [Cd5(bta)2(Hbta)2(bpy)3(H2O)2] n (7), and {[Cd4(bta)2(bpe)2(H2O)4(OH)2](H2O)2} n (8), were prepared via hydrothermal reactions based on H3nbta or H3bta (H3nbta = 5-nitro-1,2,3-benzenetricarboxylic acid and H3bta = 1,2,3-benzenetricarboxylic acid) and the dipyridyl-type coligand 4,4′-bipyridyl (bpy) or 1,2-di(4-pyridyl)ethene (bpe). All complexes were characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectra, and X-ray powder diffraction techniques. Complexes 1−4 all display unusual three-dimensional (3-D) self-penetrating coordination networks. From the topology point of view, complexes 1 and 2 display the 4-connected frameworks with the Schläfli symbols of (4.104.12)2(43.62.8)2(44.62) and (4.62.72.8)2(42.62.7.8), respectively. Complex 3 features an unprecedented 3-nodal network with (3,5,6)-connectivity and the Schläfli symbol of (52.64.72.86.10)(52.65.72.8)2(52.6)2, also exhibiting an intriguing polyrotaxane entangled motif. Complex 4 shows a new 4-connected (42.63.8)4(64.8.10) topology. Different from 1−4, complexes 5−8 based on H3bta all present the non-self-penetrating structural type. Complex 5 possesses binuclear units which are further extended to a two-dimensional (2-D) supramolecular network via extensive H-bonding interactions, showing alternate left- and right-handed helical chains. Complex 6 has a 2-D layered motif generated via H-bonding interactions between the one-dimensional (1-D) coordination chains. Complex 7 shows a 3-D coordination framework, which is constructed from the 2-D metal-carboxylate layers pillared by the rod-like bipy spacers. Complex 8 presents a 2-D net with the [Cd4(μ3-OH)2]6+ clusters as the linking nodes. These results reveal that the existence of the electron-withdrawing -NO2 group in such a tricarboxyl building block plays a critical role in structural direction of the self-penetrating coordination frameworks.

elements.content: Eight ZnII and CdII complexes based on 5-nitro-1,2,3-benzenetricarboxylic acid or 1,2,3-benzenetricarboxylic acid and different dipyridyl ligands have been hydrothermally prepared and structurally characterized. The results demonstrate that the noncoordinating substituent group of the tricarboxyl tecton can be applied as the structure-directing tool in the synthesis of unusual coordination frameworks such as the self-penetrating networks.
elements.clean_text: Eight ZnII and CdII complexes based on 5-nitro-1,2,3-benzenetricarboxylic acid or 1,2,3-benzenetricarboxylic acid and different dipyridyl ligands have been hydrothermally prepared and structurally characterized. The results demonstrate that the noncoordinating substituent group of the tricarboxyl tecton can be applied as the structure-directing tool in the synthesis of unusual coordination frameworks such as the self-penetrating networks.

elements.content: Interest in entangled supramolecular systems is rapidly increasing not only for their potential applications as functional materials but also because of their intriguing and often complicated architectures and topologies. Many topologically entangled structures have been discussed in the comprehensive reviews by Batten and Robson as well as Ciani and co-workers. In this regard, particular attention has recently been devoted to self-penetrating supramolecular patterns. Generally, self-penetration can be described as a single net in which there exist the smallest circuits that are penetrated by each other within the same network. In contrast to the fruitful production of interpenetrating networks, the self-penetrating motifs have been less studied, particularly the systematic investigations on a given organic ligand. Hitherto, only a limited number of self-penetrated nets have been observed, as evidenced in a review by Ciani et al, and moreover, most of the reported self-penetrating nets are obtained accidentally. Thus, it is a great challenge to achieve the self-penetrating patterns via a rational constructing strategy (for instance, by deliberately designing the organic tectons).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Interest in entangled supramolecular systems is rapidly increasing not only for their potential applications as functional materials but also because of their intriguing and often complicated architectures and topologies. Many topologically entangled structures have been discussed in the comprehensive reviews by Batten and Robson as well as Ciani and co-workers. In this regard, particular attention has recently been devoted to self-penetrating supramolecular patterns. Generally, self-penetration can be described as a single net in which there exist the smallest circuits that are penetrated by each other within the same network. In contrast to the fruitful production of interpenetrating networks, the self-penetrating motifs have been less studied, particularly the systematic investigations on a given organic ligand. Hitherto, only a limited number of self-penetrated nets have been observed, as evidenced in a review by Ciani et al, and moreover, most of the reported self-penetrating nets are obtained accidentally. Thus, it is a great challenge to achieve the self-penetrating patterns via a rational constructing strategy (for instance, by deliberately designing the organic tectons).

elements.content: On the other hand, it is well-known that net topology of coordination frameworks can be effectively controlled and modulated by modifying the coordination geometry of metal centers and the linking nature of organic ligands. With regard to the organic tectons, multicarboxylate ligands have usually been used as the multifunctional connectors, such as 1,n-benzenedicarboxylate (n = 2, 3, and 4), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, 1,2,4-benzenetricarboxylate, and 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate, for the construction of various coordination networks with new topological structures and promising properties. In this context, in contrast to 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid which has been extensively explored, there are only limited known examples of coordination frameworks with 1,2,3-benzenetricarboxylic acid. Of further interest, H3nbta, as a derivative of H3bta, remains largely unexplored hitherto in the field of coordination polymers. However, H3nbta may provide the potential to construct unpredictable and interesting network structures due to the existence of a noncoordinating electron-withdrawing nitro-group on the aromatic backbone, which will have a profound impact on the electron density of such a ligand and therefore different physical and chemical properties.

In this context, in contrast to 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid which has been extensively explored, there are only limited known examples of coordination frameworks with 1,2,3-benzenetricarboxylic acid. Of further interest, H3nbta, as a derivative of H3bta, remains largely unexplored hitherto in the field of coordination polymers. However, H3nbta may provide the potential to construct unpredictable and interesting network structures due to the existence of a noncoordinating electron-withdrawing nitro-group on the aromatic backbone, which will have a profound impact on the electron density of such a ligand and therefore different physical and chemical properties.

elements.content: In our previous studies, we have revealed that the existence of electron-donating or electron-withdrawing groups in the dicarboxylate derivatives may have a significant effect on the assembly of the coordination networks. In this contribution, we apply such a strategy to prepare novel coordination frameworks with interesting topologies and further demonstrate the effect of substituted group on governing the self-penetrating structures. The syntheses, structural analysis, thermal stability, and photoluminescent properties of eight ZnII and CdII complexes, namely, {[Zn3(nbta)2(bpy)2(H2O)2](H2O)2} n (1), [Zn4(nbta)2(bpe)2(OH)2] n (2), {[Cd3(nbta)2(bpy)5(H2O)2](H2O)6} n (3), {[Cd3(nbta)2(bpe)2(H2O)2](H2O)2} n (4), [Zn2(Hbta)2(bpy)2(H2O)2](H2O) (5), [Zn(bta)(Hbpe)] n (6), [Cd5(bta)2(Hbta)2(bpy)3(H2O)2] n (7), {[Cd4(bta)2(bpe)2(H2O)4(OH)2](H2O)2} n (8) (H3nbta = 5-nitro-1,2,3-benzenetricarboxylic acid, H3bta = 1,2,3-benzenetricarboxylic acid, bpy = 4,4′-bipyridyl, bpe = 1,2-di(4-pyridyl)ethene), will be presented. The change of substituent group of the tricarboxyl organic ligand leads to a modification of the resulting coordination networks (see Scheme for the ligands used in this work). To our surprise, four complicated three-dimensional self-penetrating structures (1−4) were constructed when H3nbta was used, which were not available in the corresponding complexes with H3bta (5−8), leading to the formation of distinct crystalline species with diverse structures, from discrete binuclear species, to infinite one-, two-, and three-dimensional (1-D, 2-D, and 3-D) networks.

In this contribution, we apply such a strategy to prepare novel coordination frameworks with interesting topologies and further demonstrate the effect of substituted group on governing the self-penetrating structures. The syntheses, structural analysis, thermal stability, and photoluminescent properties of eight ZnII and CdII complexes, namely, {[Zn3(nbta)2(bpy)2(H2O)2](H2O)2} n  (1), [Zn4(nbta)2(bpe)2(OH)2] n  (2), {[Cd3(nbta)2(bpy)5(H2O)2](H2O)6} n  (3), {[Cd3(nbta)2(bpe)2(H2O)2](H2O)2} n  (4), [Zn2(Hbta)2(bpy)2(H2O)2](H2O) (5), [Zn(bta)(Hbpe)] n  (6), [Cd5(bta)2(Hbta)2(bpy)3(H2O)2] n  (7), {[Cd4(bta)2(bpe)2(H2O)4(OH)2](H2O)2} n  (8) (H3nbta = 5-nitro-1,2,3-benzenetricarboxylic acid, H3bta = 1,2,3-benzenetricarboxylic acid, bpy = 4,4'-bipyridyl, bpe = 1,2-di(4-pyridyl)ethene), will be presented. The change of substituent group of the tricarboxyl organic ligand leads to a modification of the resulting coordination networks (see Scheme  for the ligands used in this work). To our surprise, four complicated three-dimensional self-penetrating structures (1-4) were constructed when H3nbta was used, which were not available in the corresponding complexes with H3bta (5-8), leading to the formation of distinct crystalline species with diverse structures, from discrete binuclear species, to infinite one-, two-, and three-dimensional (1-D, 2-D, and 3-D) networks.

A direct mixing of the solutions of metal salt and organic ligand usually results in white precipitations that are difficult to be structurally characterized, and thus, a hydrothermal method was applied in this study, which has been proven to be a powerful approach for the preparation of various crystalline materials.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

A direct mixing of the solutions of metal salt and organic ligand usually results in white precipitations that are difficult to be structurally characterized, and thus, a hydrothermal method was applied in this study, which has been proven to be a powerful approach for the preparation of various crystalline materials.

elements.content: The structure of complex 1 reveals a unique 3-D coordination framework. As shown in , there are two crystallographically independent ZnII ions, both of which take the distorted octahedral coordination geometry. Zn1 is surrounded by six O atoms from four nbta ligands, and Zn2 is ligated by four O atoms from two nbta ligands and a water molecule as well as two N donors from two bpy ligands. Interestingly, the three carboxylate groups in nbta exhibit distinct coordination fashions, including unidentate, μ-O,O′, and μ-O,O-η-O,O′ fashions, respectively (see ). In order to make an easy understanding on the complicated connecting role of the nbta ligands, only the pertinent backbones involving metal coordination are specified in the structural analysis of 1−4. In this way, the ZnII ions in 1 are connected by the nbta trianions to afford a 1-D array along the [001] direction (see Figure a), within which the ratio of Zn1/Zn2 is 1:2. Furthermore, these 1-D motifs are interconnected by the bpy bridges to form a complicated 3-D polymeric framework (see Figure b). From the viewpoint of network topology, all the ZnII centers and nbta ligands can be regarded as four-connected nodes to result in a trinodal net with the Schläfli symbol of (4.104.12)2(43.62.8)2(44.62), representing a new topological prototype (see Figure c left). The vertex symbols for Zn1, Zn2, and nbta nodes are (4.4.4.4.62.62), (4.1240.104.107.104.1013), and (4.4.4.8.6.6), respectively. Notably, this net also displays a self-penetrating pattern, within which two of the shortest 10-membered circuits (green and red in Figure c) consisting of six Zn2 and four nbta nodes are penetrated with each other (see Figure c right), which are further connected by the Zn1 bridges.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Analysis and Discussion

{[Zn3(nbta)2(bpy)2(H2O)2](H2O)2} n  (1)

The structure of complex 1 reveals a unique 3-D coordination framework. As shown in , there are two crystallographically independent ZnII ions, both of which take the distorted octahedral coordination geometry. Zn1 is surrounded by six O atoms from four nbta ligands, and Zn2 is ligated by four O atoms from two nbta ligands and a water molecule as well as two N donors from two bpy ligands. Interestingly, the three carboxylate groups in nbta exhibit distinct coordination fashions, including unidentate, μ-O,O', and μ-O,O-η-O,O' fashions, respectively (see ). In order to make an easy understanding on the complicated connecting role of the nbta ligands, only the pertinent backbones involving metal coordination are specified in the structural analysis of 1-4. In this way, the ZnII ions in 1 are connected by the nbta trianions to afford a 1-D array along the [001] direction (see Figure a), within which the ratio of Zn1/Zn2 is 1:2. Furthermore, these 1-D motifs are interconnected by the bpy bridges to form a complicated 3-D polymeric framework (see Figure b). From the viewpoint of network topology, all the ZnII centers and nbta ligands can be regarded as four-connected nodes to result in a trinodal net with the Schläfli symbol of (4.104.12)2(43.62.8)2(44.62), representing a new topological prototype (see Figure c left). The vertex symbols for Zn1, Zn2, and nbta nodes are (4.4.4.4.62.62), (4.1240.104.107.104.1013), and (4.4.4.8.6.6), respectively. Notably, this net also displays a self-penetrating pattern, within which two of the shortest 10-membered circuits (green and red in Figure c) consisting of six Zn2 and four nbta nodes are penetrated with each other (see Figure c right), which are further connected by the Zn1 bridges.

elements.content: When bpy is replaced by bpe, which has a longer and more flexible backbone, a completely different 3-D coordination polymer 2 is obtained. In the asymmetric unit of 2 (see ), there are four crystallographically independent ZnII ions, two nbta3− ligands, two bpe spacers, and two hydroxyl anions. Different from that in 1, the coordination geometry for each ZnII is a tetrahedron, which consists of one hydroxyl, one nbta, one bpe, and one water for Zn1 and Zn4, as well as one hydroxyl, two nbta, and one bpe for Zn2 and Zn3. The three carboxylate groups in the two nbta ligands display similar coordination modes, that is, monodentate, μ-O,O′, and monodentate, respectively (see ). Also, the effective backbones of network linkage for the nbta anions (types 1 and 2) are highlighted by green in and Figure a. Consequently, the ZnII ions are interlinked by the nbta ligands and hydroxyl ions to afford a novel 2-D layered network (see Figure a) with the Schläfli symbol of (4.62)2(42.62.82), in which nbta and ZnII can be considered as the 4- and 3-connecting nodes with the vertex symbols of (4.4.6.6.82.82) and (4.6.6), respectively. The adjacent 2-D layers are interconnected by the bpe spacers to form a binodal 3-D network (see Figure b), in which both ZnII ions and nbta ligands act as the 4-connected nodes. This 3-D array also represents a new net topology with the Schläfli symbol of (4.62.72.8)2(42.62.7.8) (see Figure c left). Significantly, this 3-D architecture again shows a self-penetrating pattern, in which the shortest eight-numbered loop consists of six Zn nodes and two nbta ligands, and two such rings are shown an interpenetrated prototype and further connected via coordination bonding (see Figure c right).

[Zn4(nbta)2(bpe)2(OH)2] n  (2)

When bpy is replaced by bpe, which has a longer and more flexible backbone, a completely different 3-D coordination polymer 2 is obtained. In the asymmetric unit of 2 (see ), there are four crystallographically independent ZnII ions, two nbta3- ligands, two bpe spacers, and two hydroxyl anions. Different from that in 1, the coordination geometry for each ZnII is a tetrahedron, which consists of one hydroxyl, one nbta, one bpe, and one water for Zn1 and Zn4, as well as one hydroxyl, two nbta, and one bpe for Zn2 and Zn3. The three carboxylate groups in the two nbta ligands display similar coordination modes, that is, monodentate, μ-O,O', and monodentate, respectively (see ). Also, the effective backbones of network linkage for the nbta anions (types 1 and 2) are highlighted by green in  and Figure a. Consequently, the ZnII ions are interlinked by the nbta ligands and hydroxyl ions to afford a novel 2-D layered network (see Figure a) with the Schläfli symbol of (4.62)2(42.62.82), in which nbta and ZnII can be considered as the 4- and 3-connecting nodes with the vertex symbols of (4.4.6.6.82.82) and (4.6.6), respectively. The adjacent 2-D layers are interconnected by the bpe spacers to form a binodal 3-D network (see Figure b), in which both ZnII ions and nbta ligands act as the 4-connected nodes. This 3-D array also represents a new net topology with the Schläfli symbol of (4.62.72.8)2(42.62.7.8) (see Figure c left). Significantly, this 3-D architecture again shows a self-penetrating pattern, in which the shortest eight-numbered loop consists of six Zn nodes and two nbta ligands, and two such rings are shown an interpenetrated prototype and further connected via coordination bonding (see Figure c right).

elements.content: The fundamental building unit (see ) contains two independent CdII ions. For Cd1, the distorted octahedral sphere is provided by two nbta trianions, three bpy ligands, and one water ligand, whereas that for Cd2 is completed by two nbta and four bpy ligands. There exists only one type of nbta anion in this case, and it links the CdII centers via two carboxylate groups thereof in monodentate and μ-O,O′ bridging modes, respectively (see ). As a result, a familiar 2-D (6,3) coordination layer is given and interestingly, the right and left handed [Cd(nbta)] n helical chains are observed in this motif in an alternate fashion (see Figure a). With the aid of bpy spacers, these 2-D layers are combined into a unique 3-D framework, in which the rotaxane-like subunits are found (see Figure b). A topological analysis reveals that each nbta serves as a 3-connected node to join three CdII centers, and Cd1 and Cd2 play the 5- and 6-connected role to link the nbta nodes and CdII ions via the bpy spacers (2Cd1 + 1Cd2 + 2nbta for Cd1 and 2Cd1 + 2Cd2 + 2nbta for Cd2). As a result, an unprecedented 3-nodal network with (3,5,6)-connectivity and the Schläfli symbol of (52.64.72.86.10)(52.65.72.8)2(52.6)2 is formed (see Figure c left). This 3-D architecture also shows an intriguing entangled pattern with a self-interpenetrating feature, in which two unique shortest circuits (2Cd1 + 2Cd2 and 4Cd1) are interpenetrated with each other and interconnected with the aid of nbta linkers (see Figure c right).

As a result, a familiar 2-D (6,3) coordination layer is given and interestingly, the right and left handed [Cd(nbta)] n  helical chains are observed in this motif in an alternate fashion (see Figure a). With the aid of bpy spacers, these 2-D layers are combined into a unique 3-D framework, in which the rotaxane-like subunits are found (see Figure b). As a result, an unprecedented 3-nodal network with (3,5,6)-connectivity and the Schläfli symbol of (52.64.72.86.10)(52.65.72.8)2(52.6)2 is formed (see Figure c left). This 3-D architecture also shows an intriguing entangled pattern with a self-interpenetrating feature, in which two unique shortest circuits (2Cd1 + 2Cd2 and 4Cd1) are interpenetrated with each other and interconnected with the aid of nbta linkers (see Figure c right).

elements.content: In the structure of 4, three independent CdII ions are found (see ). The Cd1 and Cd2 centers are hepta-coordinated by three nbta ligands and one bpe spacer, showing a similar distorted pentagonal-bipyramidal geometry. The Cd3 ion takes a distorted octahedral sphere that is completed by two nbta, two bpe, and a pair of water ligands. Two types of nbta trianions are found in this case, and the coordination fashions of the carboxylate groups in each nbta are μ-O,O, μ-O,O′, and μ-O,O-η-O,O′, respectively (see ). As a result, the CdII ions are extended by nbta to afford a 2-D layer (see Figure a), and such layers are further connected by the bpe spacers to constitute a 3-D coordination framework with the Schläfli symbol of (42.63.8)4(64.8.10) (see Figure b and Figure c left), which represents a new 4-connected topology type. In this case, all types of nbta anions and CdII centers can be viewed as the 4-connected nodes (1Cd1 + 2Cd2 + 1Cd3 for nbta1, 2Cd1 + 1Cd2 + Cd3 for nbta2, Cd1 + 1nbta1 + 2nbta2 for Cd1, 1Cd2 + 2nbta1 + 1nbta2 for Cd2, and 2Cd3 + 1nbta1 + 1nbta2 for Cd3). And peculiarly, each 10-membered loop containing four Cd1, two Cd2, two nbta1, and two nbta2 nodes is penetrated by the other ring building from paired Cd1, Cd2, Cd3, nbta1, and nbta2, and such two rings are further connected via coordination bonding (see Figure c right).

{[Cd3(nbta)2(bpe)2(H2O)2](H2O)2} n  (4)

In the structure of 4, three independent CdII ions are found (see ). The Cd1 and Cd2 centers are hepta-coordinated by three nbta ligands and one bpe spacer, showing a similar distorted pentagonal-bipyramidal geometry. The Cd3 ion takes a distorted octahedral sphere that is completed by two nbta, two bpe, and a pair of water ligands. Two types of nbta trianions are found in this case, and the coordination fashions of the carboxylate groups in each nbta are μ-O,O, μ-O,O', and μ-O,O-η-O,O', respectively (see ). As a result, the CdII ions are extended by nbta to afford a 2-D layer (see Figure a), and such layers are further connected by the bpe spacers to constitute a 3-D coordination framework with the Schläfli symbol of (42.63.8)4(64.8.10) (see Figure b and Figure c left), which represents a new 4-connected topology type. In this case, all types of nbta anions and CdII centers can be viewed as the 4-connected nodes (1Cd1 + 2Cd2 + 1Cd3 for nbta1, 2Cd1 + 1Cd2 + Cd3 for nbta2, Cd1 + 1nbta1 + 2nbta2 for Cd1, 1Cd2 + 2nbta1 + 1nbta2 for Cd2, and 2Cd3 + 1nbta1 + 1nbta2 for Cd3). And peculiarly, each 10-membered loop containing four Cd1, two Cd2, two nbta1, and two nbta2 nodes is penetrated by the other ring building from paired Cd1, Cd2, Cd3, nbta1, and nbta2, and such two rings are further connected via coordination bonding (see Figure c right).

elements.content: Structural analysis of the dinuclear complex 5 shows that the ZnII ion is four-coordinated with a distorted tetrahedral geometry, provided by one pyridyl N from bpy, two carboxylate O atoms from two Hbta, and one water molecule (see ). The Zn−N bond length is 2.061(2) Å, and the Zn−O distances are in the range of 1.953(2)−2.010(2) Å. The Zn1 and Zn1A ions are linked by a pair of Hbta ligands to form a dinuclear unit. Such dimeric motifs are extended into a 1-D array through H-bonding between the lattice water and coordinated water/uncoordinated carboxylate (see ). The bipy ligand adopts the unidentate coordination mode and the unligated N2 atom acts as the H-bonding acceptor from the uncoordinated carboxyl. Thus, the neighboring 1-D chains are further extended by such H-bonds (O6−H6A···N2) to form a 2-D supramolecular layer, in which the left and right helical chains appear alternately (see Figure ).

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of 6 contains one ZnII ion, one bta, and one Hbpe. As shown in , each ZnII center is tetrahedrally coordinated by one N from Hbpe and three O atoms from three bta ligands. The Zn−N bond length is 2.040(3) Å and the Zn−O lengths are in the range of 1.948(2)−2.010(2) Å. The adjacent ZnII ions are bridged by the bta ligands to afford a ladder-like 1-D array along the [010] direction. Furthermore, these 1-D motifs are decorated with the bpe terminals at both sides with an outward fashion (see ) and thus are further linked by N2−H2···O5 H-bonding to form a 2-D layer (see Figure ), in which the Hbpe ligands take the unidentate mode and the unligated N2 atoms act as the hydrogen-bonding donors.

elements.content: The structure of 8 shows a 2-D network with the tetranuclear [Cd4(μ3-OH)2]6+ clusters as nodes. The two independent CdII ions in the centrosymmetric [Cd4(μ3-OH)2]6+ SBU display the similar distorted octahedral coordination geometry (see ) but with different compositions. Cd1 is surrounded by three O atoms from two bta ligands, two O atoms from the water and hydroxyl bridges, and one N atom from a bpe ligand, whereas Cd2 is coordinated by one O atom from bta, two O atoms from two hydroxyl groups, two O atoms from two water ligands, and one N donor from bpe. As a result, the Cd4 SBUs are interconnected by the bta ligands to result in a 1-D chain (see ) and such 1-D arrays are further connected by the bpe ligands to form a 2-D layer (see Figure ).

elements.content: From the above discussion, it can be seen that the anionic carboxylate-involved ligands will have a great influence on the framework construction of such complexes. As for 1−4, the tricarboxyl ligands H3nbta are fully deprotonated and show various complicated connection modes with the ZnII and CdII centers, which play a critical role in assembling the resulting 3-D coordination networks with diverse topologies. Remarkably, this series of crystalline frameworks all possess the unique self-penetrating supramolecular feature. Interestingly, the three carboxylate groups in nbta and bta exhibit distinct coordination fashions in complexes 1−8 (see , for 5, for 6, and for 8). Of further importance, four lower-dimensional (from 0-D to 2-D) species were isolated correspondingly, under a similar synthetic condition when H3nbta is replaced by H3bta. These results undoubtedly indicate that the strongly electron-withdrawing nitro-group in the tricarboxyl backbone accurately tune the generation of self-penetrating coordination frameworks, although it is not involved in the network construction.
elements.clean_text:
Effect of the Carboxylate-Ligands on Network Assemblies

From the above discussion, it can be seen that the anionic carboxylate-involved ligands will have a great influence on the framework construction of such complexes. As for 1-4, the tricarboxyl ligands H3nbta are fully deprotonated and show various complicated connection modes with the ZnII and CdII centers, which play a critical role in assembling the resulting 3-D coordination networks with diverse topologies. Remarkably, this series of crystalline frameworks all possess the unique self-penetrating supramolecular feature. Interestingly, the three carboxylate groups in nbta and bta exhibit distinct coordination fashions in complexes 1-8 (see ,  for 5,  for 6, and  for 8). Of further importance, four lower-dimensional (from 0-D to 2-D) species were isolated correspondingly, under a similar synthetic condition when H3nbta is replaced by H3bta. These results undoubtedly indicate that the strongly electron-withdrawing nitro-group in the tricarboxyl backbone accurately tune the generation of self-penetrating coordination frameworks, although it is not involved in the network construction.

elements.content: In order to check the phase purity of these compounds, the X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns of the complexes were checked at room temperature. As shown in Figure S6 (), the peak positions of the simulated and experimental XRPD patterns are in agreement with each other, demonstrating the single phase purity of the products. The difference in intensity may be due to the preferred orientation of the microcrystalline powder samples.
elements.clean_text:
XRPD, Thermal Stability, and Fluorescent Properties

In order to check the phase purity of these compounds, the X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns of the complexes were checked at room temperature. As shown in Figure S6 (), the peak positions of the simulated and experimental XRPD patterns are in agreement with each other, demonstrating the single phase purity of the products. The difference in intensity may be due to the preferred orientation of the microcrystalline powder samples.

elements.content: Thermal stability of the complexes was investigated by the TGA technique (see Figure S7, ). Complex 1 loses the lattice and coordinated water molecules at 70−120 °C (calc. 6.6% and exp. 6.2%). The final residual weight corresponds to that of ZnO (calc. 22.5% and exp. 24.1%). The TG curves for complexes 3 and 5 are similar. The weight loss of coordinated and lattice water molecules is observed from room temperature to 200 °C for 3 and 215 °C for 5 (calc. 8.2% and exp. 8.9% for 3; calc. 5.9% and exp. 5.4% for 5). The first weight loss for complex 4 from 150 to 200 °C corresponds to the elimination of four lattice and coordinated water molecules (calc. 5.6% and exp. 5.0%), after which the weight loss is accelerated, and finally yields CdO at 800 °C (calc. 30.1% and exp. 31.6%). The TGA curve shows that a weight loss of 11.3% occurs in 60−100 °C for 8, presumably due to the removal of two lattice and coordinated water as well as two hydroxyl groups (calc. 10.4%). There is no mass loss for 2 until ca. 260 and 300 °C for 6, indicating their relatively higher thermal stability.

elements.content: Solid-state fluorescent properties of 5, 6, and 8 were studied at room temperature (see ). The maximum emissions are observed at ca. 402 nm for 5 (λex = 352 nm), 410 nm for 6 (λex = 383 nm), and 403 nm for 8 (λex = 374 nm), respectively. Meanwhile, in order to understand the nature of such emission bands, the luminescent properties of the free H3bta ligand were also measured, indicating the maximum emission at ca. 433 nm (λex = 329 nm). In comparison to that of the free carboxyl-ligand, the emission maxima of complexes 5, 6, and 8 are obviously shifted. However, since the ZnII and CdII ions are are difficultly oxidized or reduced, these bands should be assigned to the intraligand fluorescent emissions. The shifts of the emission bands are attributed to deprotonation effect of the H3nbta ligand and/or metal−ligand coordination interactions. The luminescence lifetimes [τ(H3bta) = 14.8 ns, τ(5) = 6.1 ns, τ(6) = 4.4 ns, and τ(8) = 3.2 ns] are much shorter than the lifetime of the emission resulting from a triplet-state (>10−3 s), indicating a singlet-state emission. The nanosecond range of lifetimes in solid state at room temperature also reveals that the emission is fluorescent in nature.

elements.content: Eight ZnII and CdII complexes, assembled from H3nbta or H3bta and different dipyridyl ligands, have been hydrothermally prepared and structurally characterized. Two types of coordination networks, self-penetration and non-self-penetration, have been constructed via the subtle modification of the carboxylate ligands. The results demonstrate that the noncoordinating substituent group of the tricarboxyl tecton can be well used as the structure-directing tool in the synthesis of unusual coordination frameworks such as the self-penetrating motifs in this work. As a new design strategy via ligand-elaboration for engendering the supramolecular crystalline networks, it is anticipated that other new coordination solids with intriguing self-penetrating structures and useful properties may also be synthesized in future.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Eight ZnII and CdII complexes, assembled from H3nbta or H3bta and different dipyridyl ligands, have been hydrothermally prepared and structurally characterized. Two types of coordination networks, self-penetration and non-self-penetration, have been constructed via the subtle modification of the carboxylate ligands. The results demonstrate that the noncoordinating substituent group of the tricarboxyl tecton can be well used as the structure-directing tool in the synthesis of unusual coordination frameworks such as the self-penetrating motifs in this work. As a new design strategy via ligand-elaboration for engendering the supramolecular crystalline networks, it is anticipated that other new coordination solids with intriguing self-penetrating structures and useful properties may also be synthesized in future.

elements.content: All reagents used in the synthesis and analysis were of analytical grade. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were performed on a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. Infrared spectra (4000−600 cm −1) were recorded by using the KBr pellet on an Avatar 360 E. S. P. IR spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analyses were measured on a STA449C integration thermal analyzer. The fluorescent properties were carried out on a FLS920 fluorescence spectrophotometer. The PXRD patterns were recorded with a Rigaku D/Max 3III diffractometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

All reagents used in the synthesis and analysis were of analytical grade. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were performed on a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. Infrared spectra (4000-600 cm -1) were recorded by using the KBr pellet on an Avatar 360 E. S. P. IR spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analyses were measured on a STA449C integration thermal analyzer. The fluorescent properties were carried out on a FLS920 fluorescence spectrophotometer. The PXRD patterns were recorded with a Rigaku D/Max 3III diffractometer.

elements.content: A mixture of H3nbta (50.5 mg, 0.2 mmol), 4,4′-bipy (17.9 mg, 0.1 mmol), Zn(OAc)2·2H2O (22.0 mg, 0.1 mmol), and H2O (15 mL) was placed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel, heated to 170 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature over 24 h. Colorless block crystals of 1 were obtained in 42% yield (based on Zn). Elemental analysis (%): calcd for C38H28N6O20Zn3: C 42.07, H 2.60, N 7.75; found: C 42.01, H 2.67, N 7.71. IR (cm−1): 3422 m, 1610s, 1575 m, 1425 m, 1346 m, 1290 m, 1074 m, 820 m, 725 m.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses of complexes 1−8 were performed on a Bruker SMART APEX II CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromated MoΚα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) by using a ϕ/ω scan technique at room temperature. A semiempirical absorption correction was applied by SADABS. All structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS of SHELXTL and refined with SHELXL. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms of O were located by a difference Fourier map and then refined by a riding mode with U eq = 1.5U eq(O), and the other hydrogen atoms were determined theoretically. The crystallographic data and selected bond lengths for 1−8 are listed in Tables − . Crystallographic data for the structural analysis have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center. CCDC reference numbers: 748407 (1), 748408 (2), 748409 (3), 748410(4), 748411 (5), 751185 (6), 748412 (8).

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of H3nbta (50.5 mg, 0.2 mmol), 4,4′-bipy (17.9 mg, 0.1 mmol), Zn(OAc)2·2H2O (22.0 mg, 0.1 mmol), and H2O (15 mL) was placed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel, heated to 170 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature over 24 h. Colorless block crystals of 1 were obtained in 42% yield (based on Zn). Elemental analysis (%): calcd for C38H28N6O20Zn3: C 42.07, H 2.60, N 7.75; found: C 42.01, H 2.67, N 7.71. IR (cm−1): 3422 m, 1610s, 1575 m, 1425 m, 1346 m, 1290 m, 1074 m, 820 m, 725 m.

[Zn<sub>4</sub>(nbta)<sub>2</sub>(bpe)<sub>2</sub>(OH)<sub>2</sub>]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

2 was synthesized in a similar way as that for 1, except that bipy was replaced by bpe. Yield: 36% (based on Zn). Elemental analysis (%): calcd for C42H26N6O18Zn4: C 43.33, H 2.25, N 7.22; found: C 43.28, H 2.31, N 7.18. IR (cm−1): 3455 m, 1614s, 1574 m, 1446 m, 1344 m, 1252 m, 1030 m, 827 m, 726 m.

{[Cd<sub>3</sub>(nbta)<sub>2</sub>(bpy)<sub>5</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>](H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>6</sub>}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

3 was synthesized in a similar way as that for 1, except that Zn(OAc)2·2H2O was replaced by Cd(OAc)2. Yield: 38% (based on Cd). Elemental analysis (%): calcd for C68H60Cd3N12O24: C 46.23, H 3.42, N 9.51; found: C 46.19, H 3.37, N 9.43. IR (cm−1): 3451 m, 1603s, 1416 m, 1384 m, 1344 m, 1124 m, 1071 m, 806 m, 720 m.

{[Cd<sub>3</sub>(nbta)<sub>2</sub>(bpe)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>](H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>4</bold>)

4 was synthesized in a similar way as that for 2, except that Zn(OAc)2·2H2O was replaced by Cd(OAc)2. Yield: 32% (based on Cd). Elemental analysis (%): calcd for C42H32Cd3N6O20: C 39.47, H 2.52, N 6.58; found: C 39.41, H 2.46, N 6.65. IR (cm−1): 3431 m, 1604s, 1429 m, 1347 m, 1299 m, 1126 m, 1068 m, 824 m, 724 m.

[Zn<sub>2</sub>(Hbta)<sub>2</sub>(bpy)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>](H<sub>2</sub>O) (<bold>5</bold>)

5 was synthesized in a similar way as that for 1, except that H3nbta was replaced by H3bta. Yield: 46% (based on Zn). Elemental analysis (%): calcd for C38H30N4O15Zn2: C 49.97, H 3.31, N 6.13; found: C 49.92, H 3.28, N 6.09. IR (cm−1): 3352 m, 2452 m, 1603s, 1580 m, 1382 m, 1264 m, 1069 m, 812 m, 714 m.

[Zn(bta)(Hbpe)]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>6</bold>)

6 was synthesized in a similar way as that for 2, except that H3nbta was replaced by H3bta. Yield: 31% (based on Zn). Elemental analysis (%): calcd for C21H14N2O6Zn: C 55.35, H 3.10, N 6.15; found: C 55.41, H 3.05, N 6.21. IR (cm−1): 3450 m, 3066 m, 1612 m, 1578 m, 1499 m, 1391 m, 1364 m, 1195 m, 999 m, 829 m, 771 m.

{[Cd<sub>4</sub>(bta)<sub>2</sub>(bpe)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>4</sub>(OH)<sub>2</sub>](H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>8</bold>)

8 was synthesized in a similar way as that for 4, except that H3nbta was replaced by H3bta. Yield: 48% (based on Cd). Preparation of Complexes 1-8 

{[Zn3(nbta)2(bpy)2(H2O)2](H2O)2} n  (1)

A mixture of H3nbta (50.5 mg, 0.2 mmol), 4,4'-bipy (17.9 mg, 0.1 mmol), Zn(OAc)2⋅2H2O (22.0 mg, 0.1 mmol), and H2O (15 mL) was placed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel, heated to 170 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature over 24 h. Colorless block crystals of 1 were obtained in 42% yield (based on Zn). Elemental analysis (%): calcd for C38H28N6O20Zn3: C 42.07, H 2.60, N 7.75; found: C 42.01, H 2.67, N 7.71. IR (cm-1): 3422 m, 1610s, 1575 m, 1425 m, 1346 m, 1290 m, 1074 m, 820 m, 725 m.

[Zn4(nbta)2(bpe)2(OH)2] n  (2)

 2 was synthesized in a similar way as that for 1, except that bipy was replaced by bpe. Yield: 36% (based on Zn). Elemental analysis (%): calcd for C42H26N6O18Zn4: C 43.33, H 2.25, N 7.22; found: C 43.28, H 2.31, N 7.18. IR (cm-1): 3455 m, 1614s, 1574 m, 1446 m, 1344 m, 1252 m, 1030 m, 827 m, 726 m.

{[Cd3(nbta)2(bpy)5(H2O)2](H2O)6} n  (3)

 3 was synthesized in a similar way as that for 1, except that Zn(OAc)2⋅2H2O was replaced by Cd(OAc)2. Yield: 38% (based on Cd). Elemental analysis (%): calcd for C68H60Cd3N12O24: C 46.23, H 3.42, N 9.51; found: C 46.19, H 3.37, N 9.43. IR (cm-1): 3451 m, 1603s, 1416 m, 1384 m, 1344 m, 1124 m, 1071 m, 806 m, 720 m.

{[Cd3(nbta)2(bpe)2(H2O)2](H2O)2} n  (4)

 4 was synthesized in a similar way as that for 2, except that Zn(OAc)2⋅2H2O was replaced by Cd(OAc)2. Yield: 32% (based on Cd). Elemental analysis (%): calcd for C42H32Cd3N6O20: C 39.47, H 2.52, N 6.58; found: C 39.41, H 2.46, N 6.65. IR (cm-1): 3431 m, 1604s, 1429 m, 1347 m, 1299 m, 1126 m, 1068 m, 824 m, 724 m.

[Zn2(Hbta)2(bpy)2(H2O)2](H2O) (5)

[Zn(bta)(Hbpe)] n  (6)

 6 was synthesized in a similar way as that for 2, except that H3nbta was replaced by H3bta. Yield: 31% (based on Zn). IR (cm-1): 3450 m, 3066 m, 1612 m, 1578 m, 1499 m, 1391 m, 1364 m, 1195 m, 999 m, 829 m, 771 m.

{[Cd4(bta)2(bpe)2(H2O)4(OH)2](H2O)2} n  (8)

 8 was synthesized in a similar way as that for 4, except that H3nbta was replaced by H3bta. Yield: 48% (based on Cd). cln_elements.content:
Thermal stability of the complexes was investigated by the TGA technique (see Figure S7, ). Complex 1 loses the lattice and coordinated water molecules at 70−120 °C (calc. 6.6% and exp. 6.2%). The final residual weight corresponds to that of ZnO (calc. 22.5% and exp. 24.1%). The TG curves for complexes 3 and 5 are similar. The weight loss of coordinated and lattice water molecules is observed from room temperature to 200 °C for 3 and 215 °C for 5 (calc. 8.2% and exp. 8.9% for 3; calc. 5.9% and exp. 5.4% for 5). The first weight loss for complex 4 from 150 to 200 °C corresponds to the elimination of four lattice and coordinated water molecules (calc. 5.6% and exp. 5.0%), after which the weight loss is accelerated, and finally yields CdO at 800 °C (calc. 30.1% and exp. 31.6%). The TGA curve shows that a weight loss of 11.3% occurs in 60−100 °C for 8, presumably due to the removal of two lattice and coordinated water as well as two hydroxyl groups (calc. 10.4%). There is no mass loss for 2 until ca. 260 and 300 °C for 6, indicating their relatively higher thermal stability.

Solid-state fluorescent properties of 5, 6, and 8 were studied at room temperature (see ). The maximum emissions are observed at ca. 402 nm for 5 (λex = 352 nm), 410 nm for 6 (λex = 383 nm), and 403 nm for 8 (λex = 374 nm), respectively. Meanwhile, in order to understand the nature of such emission bands, the luminescent properties of the free H3bta ligand were also measured, indicating the maximum emission at ca. 433 nm (λex = 329 nm). In comparison to that of the free carboxyl-ligand, the emission maxima of complexes 5, 6, and 8 are obviously shifted. However, since the ZnII and CdII ions are are difficultly oxidized or reduced, these bands should be assigned to the intraligand fluorescent emissions. The shifts of the emission bands are attributed to deprotonation effect of the H3nbta ligand and/or metal−ligand coordination interactions. The luminescence lifetimes [τ(H3bta) = 14.8 ns, τ(5) = 6.1 ns, τ(6) = 4.4 ns, and τ(8) = 3.2 ns] are much shorter than the lifetime of the emission resulting from a triplet-state (>10−3 s), indicating a singlet-state emission. The nanosecond range of lifetimes in solid state at room temperature also reveals that the emission is fluorescent in nature.
